elements.content: The coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n was prepared by the reaction of cadmium­(II) chloride or bromide and dipicolinic acid (dipicH2) at 60 °C under autogenous pressure. The C2/c polymorph (1) was almost exclusively obtained. However, a few crystals of the P2/c polymorph (2) were occasionally found in the mixture with the C2/c polymorph, thus making it a disappearing and concomitant polymorph. The polymeric chains in 1 are connected into dimers by π–π interaction and O–H···O hydrogen bonds. These dimers are in turn connected by intermolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds into a 2D network. The polymeric chains in 2 are connected by intermolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds into a zigzag chain along the [001] direction. According to DFT calculations, the hydrogen bonding is of similar order in both polymorphs (∼7.5 kcal mol–1 per hydrogen bond). However, there is additional stability imparted in 1, as shown by dispersion-corrected DFT, through π–π stacking between polymeric chains, making 1 the thermodynamically favored polymorph. Polymorph 1 was characterized by IR spectroscopy, PXRD analysis, and TGA and DSC methods. The DSC analysis did not show any sign of phase transition between 1 and 2. This was also confirmed by variable temperature PXRD, since the pattern of 1 remained unchanged until the decomposition of 1.

The C2/c polymorph (1) was almost exclusively obtained. However, a few crystals of the P2/c polymorph (2) were occasionally found in the mixture with the C2/c polymorph, thus making it a disappearing and concomitant polymorph. The polymeric chains in 1 are connected into dimers by π-π interaction and O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. These dimers are in turn connected by intermolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds into a 2D network. The polymeric chains in 2 are connected by intermolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds into a zigzag chain along the [001] direction. According to DFT calculations, the hydrogen bonding is of similar order in both polymorphs (~7.5 kcal mol-1 per hydrogen bond). However, there is additional stability imparted in 1, as shown by dispersion-corrected DFT, through π-π stacking between polymeric chains, making 1 the thermodynamically favored polymorph. Polymorph 1 was characterized by IR spectroscopy, PXRD analysis, and TGA and DSC methods. The DSC analysis did not show any sign of phase transition between 1 and 2. This was also confirmed by variable temperature PXRD, since the pattern of 1 remained unchanged until the decomposition of 1.

elements.content: Two polymorphs of the cadmium­(II) coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n were prepared, namely C2/c (1) and P2/c (2) polymorphs, and their crystal structures were revealed by X-ray structural analysis. DFT calculations showed that 1 is the thermodynamically stable polymorph due to the presence of π−π stacking between the polymeric chains in its structure, in agreement with the fact that 2 is the disappearing polymorph.
elements.clean_text: Two polymorphs of the cadmium(II) coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n  were prepared, namely C2/c (1) and P2/c (2) polymorphs, and their crystal structures were revealed by X-ray structural analysis. DFT calculations showed that 1 is the thermodynamically stable polymorph due to the presence of π-π stacking between the polymeric chains in its structure, in agreement with the fact that 2 is the disappearing polymorph.

elements.content: Polymorphism is the ability of a substance to exist in more than one crystalline form and has always been relevant to many industries, especially the pharmaceutical industry, since physical properties (melting point, solubility, density, conductivity, dissolution rate, etc.) can depend critically on crystal packing. It is among one of the most intensively researched areas in chemistry currently because of the tremendous basic and commercial interest in pharmaceutical solids (drugs), new materials, dyes, pigments, agrochemicals, food additives, and explosives. The conditions under which different polymorphs are obtained, exclusively or together, may provide useful information regarding the relative stability of different forms. It is important to obtain a particular polymorph under reproducible conditions, although this is not always easy to achieve. Disappearing polymorphs are usually defined as the polymorphs which cannot be crystallized reproducibly.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polymorphism is the ability of a substance to exist in more than one crystalline form and has always been relevant to many industries, especially the pharmaceutical industry, since physical properties (melting point, solubility, density, conductivity, dissolution rate, etc.) can depend critically on crystal packing. It is among one of the most intensively researched areas in chemistry currently because of the tremendous basic and commercial interest in pharmaceutical solids (drugs), new materials, dyes, pigments, agrochemicals, food additives, and explosives. The conditions under which different polymorphs are obtained, exclusively or together, may provide useful information regarding the relative stability of different forms. It is important to obtain a particular polymorph under reproducible conditions, although this is not always easy to achieve. Disappearing polymorphs are usually defined as the polymorphs which cannot be crystallized reproducibly.

elements.content: Coordination polymers are infinite systems built up with metal ions and organic ligands as the main elementary units linked via coordination bonds and other weak interactions (hydrogen bonds, π–π interactions, metal–metal interactions, metal–aromatic interactions). These materials have been extensively studied in supramolecular chemistry and material chemistry due to their structural diversity and application as porous materials, in catalysis, in ion exchange, in adsorption, in gas purification, and in storage and separation, as well as for their conducting, nonlinear optical, luminescent, and magnetic properties. Coordination polymers can extend into one, two, or three dimensions. The 1D motif may be exemplified by linear, zigzag, double, ladder-like chains or helices. In the case of 2D and 3D motifs, coordination polymers are called metal–organic frameworks. The ligands have to be multidentate with at least two donor atoms (N, O, or S donors in general), but they can differ in their charge, their shapes, their lengths (thus varying the distances between the coordination atoms), and their functionalities (presence of other heteroatoms, aromatic rings, alkyl chains).

Coordination polymers can extend into one, two, or three dimensions. The 1D motif may be exemplified by linear, zigzag, double, ladder-like chains or helices. In the case of 2D and 3D motifs, coordination polymers are called metal-organic frameworks. The ligands have to be multidentate with at least two donor atoms (N, O, or S donors in general), but they can differ in their charge, their shapes, their lengths (thus varying the distances between the coordination atoms), and their functionalities (presence of other heteroatoms, aromatic rings, alkyl chains).

elements.content: Pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, dipicolinic acid (dipicH2), is a versatile ligand with the ability to act as a bidentate, tridentate, and/or bridging ligand due to the position of its functional groups (Scheme ). Therefore, it often appears as an organic linker in coordination chemistry. It can interact with metal ions in both its fully deprotonated (dipic) and partially deprotonated forms (dipicH) and is widely used for the preparation of the various metal complexes, as evidenced by the number of coordination compounds of this ligand with cadmium alone.

elements.content: According to the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD), there are four structurally characterized cadmium­(II) coordination polymers with dipicolinate and additional ligands, e.g. methanol, 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene, (1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene, or cocrystallized complexes, e.g. a copper picolinate complex, which has been reported in the literature. The database also contains a further 12 structures containing mono-, di-, tri-, and tetrameric cadmium complexes with dipicolinate.

elements.content: Polymorphism of organic substances is a well-known phenomenon, while it is scarce in the field of coordination compounds, particularly coordination polymers. However, an increasing number of reports describe the polymorphism of coordination polymers. To the best of our knowledge, there is no report on the polymorphism of the 16 known cadmium­(II) dipicolinate complexes, and there is still no combined experimental and theoretical study on polymorphism of any coordination polymer, although such studies have been performed for discrete coordination compounds exhibiting polymorphism.

elements.content: Here, we report the preparation and characterization of two new polymorphs (C2/c (1) and P2/c (2) polymorphs) of a cadmium­(II) coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n . Structural, thermal, and density functional theory (DFT) studies were carried out to obtain detailed knowledge on the differences between the two polymorphic forms and to understand the interactions taking place.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report the preparation and characterization of two new polymorphs (C2/c (1) and P2/c (2) polymorphs) of a cadmium(II) coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n . Structural, thermal, and density functional theory (DFT) studies were carried out to obtain detailed knowledge on the differences between the two polymorphic forms and to understand the interactions taking place.

elements.content: The coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n was prepared by the reaction of cadmium­(II) chloride or bromide and dipicolinic acid in the ratio 1:1 at 60 or 80 °C under autogenous pressure. At a concentration of 0.03 M of the starting components, the formation of the polymer was observed after 2–14 days. However, when this concentration was increased to 0.06 M, the published dimer, [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)6]·2dipicH2, concomitantly appeared after 7 days if cadmium­(II) bromide was used (the pure polymer was observed after 2–3 days), or even after 2 days if cadmium­(II) chloride was used. The polymer was exclusively observed at this concentration after 10–14 days, but only if cadmium­(II) chloride was used. Higher concentrations than 0.06 M led to the exclusive or concomitant crystallization of the dimer or a variety of tetramers. The use of other cadmium­(II) salts, e.g. nitrate or sulfate at a concentration of 0.03 M, led to the formation of the same polymer. Also, if dipicolinic acid was undissolved prior to the reaction, the polymer was still produced.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Chemical Studies

The coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n  was prepared by the reaction of cadmium(II) chloride or bromide and dipicolinic acid in the ratio 1:1 at 60 or 80 °C under autogenous pressure. At a concentration of 0.03 M of the starting components, the formation of the polymer was observed after 2-14 days. However, when this concentration was increased to 0.06 M, the published dimer, [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)6]⋅2dipicH2,  concomitantly appeared after 7 days if cadmium(II) bromide was used (the pure polymer was observed after 2-3 days), or even after 2 days if cadmium(II) chloride was used. The polymer was exclusively observed at this concentration after 10-14 days, but only if cadmium(II) chloride was used. Higher concentrations than 0.06 M led to the exclusive or concomitant crystallization of the dimer or a variety of tetramers. The use of other cadmium(II) salts, e.g. nitrate or sulfate at a concentration of 0.03 M, led to the formation of the same polymer. Also, if dipicolinic acid was undissolved prior to the reaction, the polymer was still produced.

elements.content: The polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n appears in two polymorphic forms: C2/c (1) and P2/c (2) polymorphs. The formation of 2 seems to be controlled by kinetic factors, while the thermodynamically stable polymorph is 1. Polymorph 2 was initially prepared from cadmium­(II) bromide, while 1 was prepared by using both the chloride and bromide salts. Polymorph 2 can be described as a disappearing polymorph, since all attempts to reproduce this form under reproducible experimental conditions have failed and resulted in the thermodynamically stable polymorph 1. From time to time, the elusive polymorph 2 was obtained in the mixture with the stable polymorph 1, under totally nonreproducible experimental conditions, making it also a concomitant polymorph. The elusive polymorph 2 was probably formed first and then converted into thermodynamically stable polymorph 1 by a slurry process, since it was observed only if the suspension of cadmium­(II) salt and dipicolinic acid was used as a reaction mixture. Interestingly, it was never observed if the reactants were dissolved completely prior to the reaction. Thus, polymorph 2 can be formed only in the slurry, and the reason for its disappearance may simply be conversion into thermodynamically more stable polymorph 1.

elements.content: Polymorph 2 was identified by X-ray structural analysis only, and it could not be produced in a sufficient amount for further physical and chemical characterization, since just a few crystals of 2 were obtained and separated mechanically from the bulk composed of the crystals of 1. The crystals of polymorphs 1 and 2 are air-stable and colorless and can be distinguished by their morphology. The crystals of 1 crystallized as needles, while the crystals of 2 crystallized as prisms.

elements.content: The coordination environment of each cadmium­(II) ion can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid and consists of the pyridine N (N1 or N2 atoms for both 1 and 2) and two bridging carboxylate O atoms from a pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate ligand, bound in a O,N,O′-tridentate fashion (O3, O5 or O8, O10 for 1 and O3, O5 or O9, O11 for 2), one bridging carboxylate O atom from the second dipicolinate ligand (O8 or O3 for 1 and O9 or O5 for 2), and one bridging water molecule in the equatorial positions (O2 or O2ii for 1 and O2 or O8 for 2). Furthermore, one terminal water molecule (O1 or O7 for both 1 and 2) and a bridging carboxylate O atom (O10i or O5ii for 1 and O3iii or O11iv for 2) are placed in axial positions (∠O1–Cd1–O10i, 161.0­(1)° and ∠O7–Cd2–O5ii, 166.3(1)° for 1; ∠O1–Cd1–O3iii, 162.58­(8)° and ∠O7–Cd2–O11iv, 168.17­(8)° for 2; symmetry codes (i): x, –y, z – 1/2; (ii): x, –y, z + 1/2; (iii): –x, y, –z + 1/2; (iv): 1 – x, y, –z + 1/2) (Figures and ). These two crystallographically independent cadmium­(II) ions are joined by the mentioned bridging carboxylate O atoms (O3 and O8 for 1 and O5 and O9 for 2) into a Cd2O2 parallelogram, leading to the formation of a pseudocentrosymmetric binuclear unit which forms the basic repeating unit of the polymer. The Cd···Cd distances for 1 and 2 are 3.823(1) and 3.848(1) Å, respectively. Along the [001] and [100] directions in 1 and 2, respectively, the binuclear units are in turn connected on either side by two bridging carboxylate O atoms and by one bridging water molecule, forming a polymeric chain (Figure ). In the case of 1, these carboxylate atoms are O5, O10i, O5ii, and O10, and the water molecules are O2 and O2ii, while, in the case of 2, the carboxylate atoms are O3, O3iii, O11, and O11iv and the water molecules are O2 and O8. As a consequence, another Cd2O3 binuclear core with a trigonal-bipyramidal shape (Cd atoms are placed in the axial positions of the bipyramid) is formed (Cd···Cd separation, on both sides of Cd2O2 unit, of 3.4379(5) Å for 1 and 3.4431(5) and 3.4120(5) Å for 2). The coordination mode of dipicolinate ligand in 1 and 2 is the same as in the previously reported cadmium­(II) polymer. The bond angles around cadmium­(II) ions indicate a distortion from the ideal pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry which is also reflected in the bite angles N1–Cd1–O3, N1–Cd1–O5, N2–Cd2–O8, and N2–Cd2–O10 for 1 with values in the range 67.0(1)–69.1(1)° and in the bite angles N1–Cd1–O3, N1–Cd1–O5, N2–Cd2–O9, and N2–Cd2–O11 for 2 with values in the range 66.53(8)–69.19(8)° (Table S1 in the ). The Cd–N and Cd–O bond distances in these polymorphs (Table ) are comparable with the corresponding ones reported in the literature for related mononuclear, binuclear, and polynuclear cadmium­(II) complexes with dipicolinic acid or with its ethyl ester or with 4-hydroxydipicolinic acid.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 is repeated by a c glide to produce the polymeric chain extending in the [001] direction, while the asymmetric unit of 2 is repeated by a 2-fold axis to give a polymeric chain extending in the [100] direction. Even though the respective polymers are built up in crystallographically distinct manners, the pseudocentrosymmetry of the binuclear units leads to polymers which are nearly superimposable, having identical chemical connectivity (Figure a). This is exemplified by the overlay of these polymers in Figure b.

elements.content: There are intramolecular and intermolecular O–H···O and weak intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds in the crystal packing of 1 and 2 (Table ). Water molecule O atoms act as proton donors, while uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms act as proton acceptors in hydrogen bonding in both 1 and 2. The coordinated carboxylate O10 atom also participates as proton acceptor in hydrogen bonding in 1.

Viewing the crystal packing of polymorphs 1 and 2 down a common structural direction (as in Figures and ) reveals their close similarity. In both structures, adjacent polymeric chains along the [001] and [100] directions for 1 and 2, respectively, are related by a center of inversion. In 1, the centers of inversion have two types of chemical environments, while, in 2, there is only one type of chemical environment for the center of inversion between adjacent polymeric chains. The polymeric chains in 1 are first related to each other by a center of inversion which connects these into dimers by π–π interactions and O–H···O hydrogen bonds along the [100] direction. In turn, these dimers are also related to each other by a center of inversion and connected along the [100] and [010] directions by intermolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds, resulting in a 2D network of H-bonded polymeric chains (if viewed in the ab plane) (Figure ). The polymeric chains in 2 are also related by a center of inversion and connected by intermolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds into a zigzag chain extending in the [001] direction (if viewed in the bc plane). The 2D network is formed by assembling the mentioned zigzag chains by weak C–H···O hydrogen bonds in the [010] direction (Figure ). The π–π stacking interaction in the structure of 1 is formed between pyridine rings [centroid–centroid distance 3.625(3) Å, the angle between the planes 5°; the perpendicular distance between the planes 3.202(2) Å; the slippage 1.700 Å]. It is notable that the unit cells of 1 and 2 are very similar, with the major difference being that a c-axis in 2 is approximately half of the a-axis in 1. It seems possible to transform the structure of 2 into the structure of 1 by translation of any two adjacent polymeric chains in 2 in opposite directions along the [010] direction. Small translations along the [100] and [001] directions are also necessary for a more complete overlay.

elements.content: Polymorph 1 is stable up to 160 °C, and it decomposes in three steps (TG/DTG curve for 1 in the ). Three coordinated water molecules (observed weight loss 9.2%, calculated 8.9%) are released at 193.2 °C (maximum at DTG curve) during the first step. The thermal decomposition continues with a release of a dipicolinate ligand at 386.4 °C (observed weight loss 29.6%, calculated 27.1%). The final step corresponds to the partial pyrolysis of the rest of the organic component (observed weight loss 11.1% at 489.9 °C; observed residue 50.1% at 600 °C).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Polymorph 1 is stable up to 160 °C, and it decomposes in three steps (TG/DTG curve for 1 in the ). Three coordinated water molecules (observed weight loss 9.2%, calculated 8.9%) are released at 193.2 °C (maximum at DTG curve) during the first step. The thermal decomposition continues with a release of a dipicolinate ligand at 386.4 °C (observed weight loss 29.6%, calculated 27.1%). The final step corresponds to the partial pyrolysis of the rest of the organic component (observed weight loss 11.1% at 489.9 °C; observed residue 50.1% at 600 °C).

elements.content: The release of water molecules can also be visually confirmed by using hot-stage microscopy. The bubbles, corresponding to water vapor, appear at 190 °C in the silicon oil, in which the sample was heated.
elements.clean_text: The release of water molecules can also be visually confirmed by using hot-stage microscopy. The bubbles, corresponding to water vapor, appear at 190 °C in the silicon oil, in which the sample was heated.

elements.content: The DSC trace does not show any sign of melting or phase transition for 1, and it is consistent with the results from TG/DTG experiments (DSC curve for 1 in the ). It shows one broad endothermic peak, corresponding to the release of coordinated water molecules, with two temperatures assigned (192.6 and 211.6 °C). The first temperature is consistent with the one from the DTG curve. The onset temperature is 167.0 °C, and the corresponding energy change for this step is 374.4 J g–1 (228.0 kJ mol–1). The existence of two temperature values for this step suggests that it may be composed of two different processes. However, this was not confirmed by TG analysis.

elements.content: A powder XRD analysis was used to confirm the bulk content of the samples. However, the calculated powder XRD traces from the single crystal data for 1 and 2 agree closely, so this method may be less useful in distinguishing the two polymorphs in their mixtures, especially if preferred orientation effects are present. Variable temperature powder XRD (Figure ) was performed on 1 at 30, 100, 150, 200, and 250 °C to investigate a possible phase transition from 1 to 2. The PXRD trace is the same (corresponding to 1) for up to 150 °C, confirming the high thermal stability of 1, already known from TG measurements. The relative intensities decrease in the trace at 200 °C, while they completely disappear in the trace at 250 °C. The obvious loss of crystallinity upon heating is related to the removal of coordinated water molecules from 1. This removal starts above 190 °C, and it is completely finished at 250 °C, leading to a completely amorphous material at that temperature. No phase transformation to polymorph 2 occurred during this experiment.

However, the calculated powder XRD traces from the single crystal data for 1 and 2 agree closely, so this method may be less useful in distinguishing the two polymorphs in their mixtures, especially if preferred orientation effects are present. The PXRD trace is the same (corresponding to 1) for up to 150 °C, confirming the high thermal stability of 1, already known from TG measurements. The relative intensities decrease in the trace at 200 °C, while they completely disappear in the trace at 250 °C. The obvious loss of crystallinity upon heating is related to the removal of coordinated water molecules from 1. This removal starts above 190 °C, and it is completely finished at 250 °C, leading to a completely amorphous material at that temperature. No phase transformation to polymorph 2 occurred during this experiment.

elements.content: Infrared spectroscopy data confirm the coordination of dipicolinate ligand to cadmium­(II) ion via the carboxylate group in 1 (IR spectrum for 1 in the ). The band associated with the antisymmetric stretching vibrational mode, νas(−COO–) appears at 1587 cm–1 in 1 (1699 cm–1 in the free ligand), while the band associated with the symmetric stretching vibrational mode, νs(−COO–), appears at 1375 cm–1 in 1 (1332 cm–1 in the free ligand). The value of Δ­(νas(−COO–) – νs(−COO–)) amounts to 212 cm–1 for 1, indicating the presence of a carboxylate group coordinated to cadmium­(II) ion in the unidentate mode. The carboxylate group is considered to be bridging only if both carboxylate oxygen atoms are coordinated to two different metal ions. In the case of 1, only one carboxylate oxygen atom is coordinated to cadmium­(II) ions, with the other being uncoordinated, which resembles the unidentate mode of coordination for the carboxylate group. The value of Δ is in accordance with this assumption.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

Infrared spectroscopy data confirm the coordination of dipicolinate ligand to cadmium(II) ion via the carboxylate group in 1 (IR spectrum for 1 in the ). The band associated with the antisymmetric stretching vibrational mode, νas(-COO-) appears at 1587 cm-1 in 1 (1699 cm-1 in the free ligand), while the band associated with the symmetric stretching vibrational mode, νs(-COO-), appears at 1375 cm-1 in 1 (1332 cm-1 in the free ligand). The value of Δ(νas(-COO-) - νs(-COO-)) amounts to 212 cm-1 for 1, indicating the presence of a carboxylate group coordinated to cadmium(II) ion in the unidentate mode. The carboxylate group is considered to be bridging only if both carboxylate oxygen atoms are coordinated to two different metal ions. In the case of 1, only one carboxylate oxygen atom is coordinated to cadmium(II) ions, with the other being uncoordinated, which resembles the unidentate mode of coordination for the carboxylate group. The value of Δ is in accordance with this assumption.

elements.content: The band of medium intensity at 3381 cm–1 in the spectrum of 1 corresponds to the stretching vibrational mode of the water molecule, ν­(O–H), and the broadness of this band indicates the presence of hydrogen bonds involving water molecules in 1.
elements.clean_text: The band of medium intensity at 3381 cm-1 in the spectrum of 1 corresponds to the stretching vibrational mode of the water molecule, ν(O-H), and the broadness of this band indicates the presence of hydrogen bonds involving water molecules in 1.

elements.content: For calculation, fragments were extracted from the crystal structure coordinates. For the structure of 2, a single fragment was used, and for the structure of 1, two fragments were extracted. The interaction in the structure of 2 can be represented by a common motif throughout the structure consisting of two strands; these are marked I and II (P2/c fragment) in Figure . In polymorph 1, however, the interaction needs to be represented by two differing motifs; these are directly adjacent (C2/c-A fragment, with strands marked III and IV in Figure ) as well as diagonal (C2/c-D fragment, with strands marked IV and V in Figure ). The three fragments were chosen to represent these interacting motifs (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

For calculation, fragments were extracted from the crystal structure coordinates. For the structure of 2, a single fragment was used, and for the structure of 1, two fragments were extracted. The interaction in the structure of 2 can be represented by a common motif throughout the structure consisting of two strands; these are marked I and II (P2/c fragment) in Figure . In polymorph 1, however, the interaction needs to be represented by two differing motifs; these are directly adjacent (C2/c-A fragment, with strands marked III and IV in Figure ) as well as diagonal (C2/c-D fragment, with strands marked IV and V in Figure ). The three fragments were chosen to represent these interacting motifs (Figure ).

elements.content: View of the crystal packing showing the strands extracted for the DFT calculations. Strands I and II make up the P2/c fragment. Strands III and IV make up fragment C2/c-A, and using strands IV and V results in fragment C2/c-D.
elements.clean_text: 7  View of the crystal packing showing the strands extracted for the DFT calculations. Strands I and II make up the P2/c fragment. Strands III and IV make up fragment C2/c-A, and using strands IV and V results in fragment C2/c-D.

elements.content: Crystal structure fragments used in the interaction energy calculations: (a) the P2/c fragment, (b) the C2/c-D fragment, and (c) the C2/c-A fragment.

elements.content: The hydrogen bonding interactions in each fragment comprises four nearly symmetrical hydrogen bonds. The hydrogen bonds are formed when a water molecule, oxygen-coordinated to the cadmium metal, donates a hydrogen to a carboxylate oxygen in the same strand, and to a carboxylate oxygen in the adjacent strand. For the structure of 2, the PBE/6-31+G­(d,p) interaction energy per pair (between strands) is −15.2 kcal mol–1. The structure of 1, with two different hydrogen bonding patterns, gives −10.4 kcal mol–1 and −19.4 kcal mol–1, respectively, per pair. The latter, significantly stronger, interaction occurs when the strands are diagonally aligned (C2/c-D). The geometry of the hydrogen bonding motifs mirrors these results. For the structure of 2, with its intermediately strong hydrogen bonds, the O–H···O distances are 1.780 and 1.830 Å, whereas, for the C2/c-A fragment, these parameters are 1.853 and 1.854 Å, and for the C2/c-D fragment, with the strongest hydrogen bonding, they are 1.717 and 1.714 Å. Using this functional, the interaction strength is thus nearly identical, being 7.6 kcal mol–1 per hydrogen bond for 2 and 7.5 kcal mol–1 for 1.

elements.content: Given the nature of this DFT functional, however, the contribution of dispersion interaction (π–π stacking through the dipicolinate pyridine rings) is expected to be underestimated. This can be evaluated by calculating the interaction between a single water donor and a pyridine acceptor in the absence of stacked rings, for comparison. In this calculation, which, of course, neglects the effect of polarization by the surroundings, hydrogen bond strengths are approximately 10 kcal mol–1 per pair.

elements.content: Moellmann and Grimme have shown that noncovalent interactions can be of significance in explaining packing preferences for systems having thiophene π–π interactions. We therefore calculated the effect of dispersion by utilizing a dispersion-corrected atom-centered potential such as B97-D. The B97-D/6-31+G­(d,p)//PBE/3-21G interaction energy is −30.5 kcal mol–1 for P2/c. Significantly though, for C2/c-A, this rises to −43.0 kcal mol–1, and for C2/c-D, it rises to −29.6 kcal mol–1. For similarly sized fragments, the interaction is thus 11.7 kcal mol–1 stronger in the structure of 1. This was further verified by also using the hybrid meta-GGA functional M06-2X, which was fit to reproduce noncovalent interactions and does not include an explicit dispersion correction. Here also, the individual interactions are as follows: P2/c, −22.4 kcal mol–1; C2/c-A, −32.9 kcal mol–1; C2/c-D, −23.3 kcal mol–1. The result is the same, with an increase of 11.4 kcal mol–1 when the fragments are adjacently aligned.

elements.content: The coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n was prepared by the reaction of cadmium­(II) chloride or bromide and dipicolinic acid at 60 °C under autogenous pressure. The polymorph 1 was almost exclusively obtained and could be isolated in the pure form, which was confirmed with powder X-ray diffraction. However, a few crystals of polymorph 2 were occasionally found in the mixture with polymorph 1, but its preparation was not reproducible and it could never be obtained in pure form, thus making it a new example of a disappearing and concomitant polymorph. We carried out DFT calculations that showed the interaction energy between the polymeric chains in both polymorphs is nearly identical, being 7.6 kcal mol–1 per hydrogen bond for 2 and 7.5 kcal mol–1 for 1. However, if the contribution of the dispersion interactions, e.g. the π–π stacking interaction was also taken into account, it was shown that the interaction energy between the chains was generally the same, but with an increase of 11.4 kcal mol–1 when the polymeric chains are π–π stacked (only in 1). Therefore, the hydrogen bonding is of similar order in both polymorphs, but there is an additional stability through π–π stacking between the polymeric chains in 1 that makes polymorph 1 thermodynamically more stable than 2. This also explains the experimental fact that 1 can be prepared and isolated in the pure form under reproducible conditions, while this is not the case for the disappearing polymorph 2. Apparently, the nonreproducible kinetic factors during some crystallization experiments enable the occasional formation of the thermodynamically nonfavored, and thus disappearing, polymorph 2. It seems that 2 can be occasionally formed only in the slurry, when the reactants were not dissolved completely prior to the reaction, and it is then converted into more stable polymorph 1. Therefore, it is experimentally possible to observe either mixture of both polymorphs or just pure polymorph 1.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The coordination polymer [Cd2(dipic)2(H2O)3] n  was prepared by the reaction of cadmium(II) chloride or bromide and dipicolinic acid at 60 °C under autogenous pressure. The polymorph 1 was almost exclusively obtained and could be isolated in the pure form, which was confirmed with powder X-ray diffraction. However, a few crystals of polymorph 2 were occasionally found in the mixture with polymorph 1, but its preparation was not reproducible and it could never be obtained in pure form, thus making it a new example of a disappearing and concomitant polymorph. We carried out DFT calculations that showed the interaction energy between the polymeric chains in both polymorphs is nearly identical, being 7.6 kcal mol-1 per hydrogen bond for 2 and 7.5 kcal mol-1 for 1. However, if the contribution of the dispersion interactions, e.g. the π-π stacking interaction was also taken into account, it was shown that the interaction energy between the chains was generally the same, but with an increase of 11.4 kcal mol-1 when the polymeric chains are π-π stacked (only in 1). Therefore, the hydrogen bonding is of similar order in both polymorphs, but there is an additional stability through π-π stacking between the polymeric chains in 1 that makes polymorph 1 thermodynamically more stable than 2. This also explains the experimental fact that 1 can be prepared and isolated in the pure form under reproducible conditions, while this is not the case for the disappearing polymorph 2. Apparently, the nonreproducible kinetic factors during some crystallization experiments enable the occasional formation of the thermodynamically nonfavored, and thus disappearing, polymorph 2. It seems that 2 can be occasionally formed only in the slurry, when the reactants were not dissolved completely prior to the reaction, and it is then converted into more stable polymorph 1. Therefore, it is experimentally possible to observe either mixture of both polymorphs or just pure polymorph 1.

All chemicals were of reagent grade, purchased from commercial sources, and used without further purification.

The IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1, using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer.

Hot-stage microscopy was performed on a Nikon SMZ-10 stereoscopic microscope fitted with a Linkam THMS600 hot stage and a Linkam TP92 control unit.

TG/DTG measurements were performed at the heating rate 10 °C min–1 in the temperature range 25–600 °C, under a dry nitrogen flow of 60 mL min–1 on a TGA Q500 instrument. Approximately 5 mg of sample were placed in an open aluminum crucible.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All chemicals were of reagent grade, purchased from commercial sources, and used without further purification.

The IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1, using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer.

Hot-stage microscopy was performed on a Nikon SMZ-10 stereoscopic microscope fitted with a Linkam THMS600 hot stage and a Linkam TP92 control unit.

TG/DTG measurements were performed at the heating rate 10 °C min-1 in the temperature range 25-600 °C, under a dry nitrogen flow of 60 mL min-1 on a TGA Q500 instrument. Approximately 5 mg of sample were placed in an open aluminum crucible.

elements.content: DSC measurements were performed at the heating rate 10 °C min–1 in the temperature range 25–400 °C, under a dry nitrogen flow of 50 mL min–1 on a DSC Q200 instrument. Approximately 1 mg of sample was placed in an aluminum pan with a lid. A sealed and empty pan was used as a reference. The instrument was calibrated by using standard materials (In and Zn).
elements.clean_text: DSC measurements were performed at the heating rate 10 °C min-1 in the temperature range 25-400 °C, under a dry nitrogen flow of 50 mL min-1 on a DSC Q200 instrument. Approximately 1 mg of sample was placed in an aluminum pan with a lid. A sealed and empty pan was used as a reference. The instrument was calibrated by using standard materials (In and Zn).

elements.content: Powder XRD analysis was performed on a HUBER-Guinier 670 Imaging Plate X-ray powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å) generated by a Philips X-ray generator at 40 kV and 20 mA. A sample was placed in a 1 mm capillary tube, and a pattern was acquired under ambient conditions in transmission mode while the sample oscillated perpendicular to the beam. Variable temperature powder XRD was done by using a HUBER furnace whose calibrations show temperature control to within 1 °C of the set temperature.

A sample was placed in a 1 mm capillary tube, and a pattern was acquired under ambient conditions in transmission mode while the sample oscillated perpendicular to the beam. Variable temperature powder XRD was done by using a HUBER furnace whose calibrations show temperature control to within 1 °C of the set temperature.

elements.content: Dipicolinic acid (0.03 g, 0.18 mmol) was dissolved in water (5 mL) by heating. Then an aqueous solution (2 mL) of cadmium­(II) chloride monohydrate (0.04 g, 0.20 mmol) was added into the above-mentioned solution [c(CdCl2·H2O) = c(dipicolinic acid) = 0.03 M]. The clear solution was placed in a glass vial, sealed with a plastic cap, and heated at 60 °C for 3 days. The colorless needle-like crystals, formed during that period, were then filtered off, washed with mother liquor, and dried in air. Yield: 0.04 g (80%). Alternatively, cadmium­(II) bromide (0.08 g, 0.29 mmol) in 2 mL of water and dipicolinic acid (0.05 g, 0.30 mmol) in 5 mL of water can be used as the starting materials. IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3381­(s), 1587­(s), 1439­(s), 1375­(s), 1279­(m), 1188­(m), 1156­(w), 1084­(m), 1019­(m), 956­(w), 903­(m), 860­(w), 813­(m), 769­(m), 721­(s), 665­(m), 597­(m), 535­(w), 473­(w), 436­(w).

elements.content:
This experimental procedure generally led to the formation of just polymorph 1, but sometimes it lead to the formation of a mixture of both polymorphs 1 and 2, as was confirmed by PXRD analysis.

Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analysis and Structure Determination

Suitable single crystals of 1 and 2 were selected and mounted in air onto a loop. The data collection for 1 was carried out with a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer at 173(2) K using an Oxford Cryostream 600. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed using DENZO, and the space group was determined from systematic absences by XPREP and further justified by the refinement results. The data collection for 2 was carried out with a Bruker DUO APEX II CCD diffractometer at 173(2) K using an Oxford Cryostream 700. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed using SAINT-Plus, and the space group was determined from systematic absences by XPREP and further justified by the refinement results. Graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation was used in both cases.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction data have been corrected for Lorentz-polarization factor and scaled for absorption effects by multiscan using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, implemented in SHELXS-97. Refinement procedure by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2 values against all reflections have been performed by SHELXL-97, including anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-H atoms.

elements.content: The positions of hydrogen atoms belonging to the carbon atoms Csp2 were geometrically optimized by applying a riding model (Csp2 –H, 0.95 Å; U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C)). The positions of hydrogen atoms belonging to water molecules were calculated by the method of Nardelli. The distance between the water oxygen atoms and the corresponding hydrogen atoms was restrained to the average value of 0.84 Å using SHELXL-97 DFIX instruction. The isotropic U iso(H) values were fixed at the same time (U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O)).

elements.content: Calculations concerning the molecular geometry, the affirmation of chosen space groups, the analysis of hydrogen bonds, and π–π interactions were performed with PLATON. The molecular graphics were done with ORTEP-3 and MERCURY (Version 2.3). The calculated PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 were generated by Lazy Pulverix. The input to this program included atomic fractional coordinates, thermal parameters, and space group data. The rms value for the overlay was calculated with MERCURY (Version 2.3).

Density functional theory (DFT) geometry optimizations, keeping the non-hydrogen atoms fixed at the crystal structure coordinates, were done using the PBE functional and a small 3-21G basis set, with subsequent single point energy calculations using the PBE functional, the 6-31+G­(d,p) basis set for nonmetal atoms, and the LanL2DZ effective core potential (ECP) for the cadmium. Further calculations were also performed using the meta-GGA hybrid M06-2X as well as dispersion-corrected DFT, using the B97-D functional (note that this functional uses the DFT-D2 correction from 2006). This allowed for the determination of interaction energies between chosen fragments. Interaction energy was calculated as follows: E int AB = E [ AB ] − ( E [ A AB ] + E [ B AB ] ) where E[AB] is the energy of the complete polymer fragment and E[AAB] and E[BAB] is the energy of constituent strands, using the fixed coordinates from the interacting fragment. Gaussian 09 was used for all calculations.

Computational Details

Density functional theory (DFT) geometry optimizations, keeping the non-hydrogen atoms fixed at the crystal structure coordinates, were done using the PBE functional and a small 3-21G basis set, with subsequent single point energy calculations using the PBE functional, the 6-31+G(d,p) basis set for nonmetal atoms, and the LanL2DZ effective core potential (ECP) for the cadmium. Further calculations were also performed using the meta-GGA hybrid M06-2X as well as dispersion-corrected DFT, using the B97-D functional (note that this functional uses the DFT-D2 correction from 2006). This allowed for the determination of interaction energies between chosen fragments. Interaction energy was calculated as follows:    E   int   AB   = E  [ AB ]  -  ( E  [   A   AB   ]  + E  [   B   AB   ]  )   where E[AB] is the energy of the complete polymer fragment and E[AAB] and E[BAB] is the energy of constituent strands, using the fixed coordinates from the interacting fragment. Gaussian 09 was used for all calculations.

Polymorph 1 is stable up to 160 °C, and it decomposes in three steps (TG/DTG curve for 1 in the ). Three coordinated water molecules (observed weight loss 9.2%, calculated 8.9%) are released at 193.2 °C (maximum at DTG curve) during the first step. The thermal decomposition continues with a release of a dipicolinate ligand at 386.4 °C (observed weight loss 29.6%, calculated 27.1%). The final step corresponds to the partial pyrolysis of the rest of the organic component (observed weight loss 11.1% at 489.9 °C; observed residue 50.1% at 600 °C).

The DSC trace does not show any sign of melting or phase transition for 1, and it is consistent with the results from TG/DTG experiments (DSC curve for 1 in the ). It shows one broad endothermic peak, corresponding to the release of coordinated water molecules, with two temperatures assigned (192.6 and 211.6 °C). The first temperature is consistent with the one from the DTG curve. The onset temperature is 167.0 °C, and the corresponding energy change for this step is 374.4 J g–1 (228.0 kJ mol–1). The existence of two temperature values for this step suggests that it may be composed of two different processes. However, this was not confirmed by TG analysis.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Polymorph 1 is stable up to 160 °C, and it decomposes in three steps (TG/DTG curve for 1 in the ). Three coordinated water molecules (observed weight loss 9.2%, calculated 8.9%) are released at 193.2 °C (maximum at DTG curve) during the first step. The thermal decomposition continues with a release of a dipicolinate ligand at 386.4 °C (observed weight loss 29.6%, calculated 27.1%). The final step corresponds to the partial pyrolysis of the rest of the organic component (observed weight loss 11.1% at 489.9 °C; observed residue 50.1% at 600 °C).

The DSC trace does not show any sign of melting or phase transition for 1, and it is consistent with the results from TG/DTG experiments (DSC curve for 1 in the ). It shows one broad endothermic peak, corresponding to the release of coordinated water molecules, with two temperatures assigned (192.6 and 211.6 °C). The first temperature is consistent with the one from the DTG curve. The onset temperature is 167.0 °C, and the corresponding energy change for this step is 374.4 J g-1 (228.0 kJ mol-1). The existence of two temperature values for this step suggests that it may be composed of two different processes. However, this was not confirmed by TG analysis.

decomposition temperature.type: partial pyrolysis of the organic component

cln_elements.content: View of the crystal packing of 2 in the bc plane.
